command-def.name: uniq - report or filter out repeated lines in a usually pre-sorted file
command-def.synopsis: ORIGINAL: uniq [-c|-d|-u][-f fields][-s char][input_file [output_file]] CURRENT: uniq [-c|-d|-u][-g][input_file]

methods.method:
Reads from the standard input and compares adjacent lines, writing one copy of each input line on the output. The second and succeeding copies of repeated adjacent input lines are not written to the output.
Note that repeated lines in the input are not detected if they are not adjacent (see --global or -g option); sorted input lines always result in unique output lines.

Reads from the specified input {@code file} and compares adjacent lines, writing one copy of each input line on the output. The second and succeeding copies of repeated adjacent input lines are not written to the output.
Note that repeated lines in the input are not detected if they are not adjacent (see --global or -g option); sorted input lines always result in unique output lines.

Reads the file specified by its {@code path} and compares adjacent lines, writing one copy of each input line on the output. The second and succeeding copies of repeated adjacent input lines are not written to the output.
Note that repeated lines in the input are not detected if they are not adjacent (see --global or -g option); sorted input lines always result in unique output lines.

Reads from the standard input and compares adjacent lines, writing one copy of each input line on the output. The second and succeeding copies of repeated adjacent input lines are not written to the output.
Note that repeated non-adjacent lines in the input are only detected with the --global or -g option. In other words, unique output lines are guaranteed only if either (a) the --global or -g option is specified, or (b) the input lines are sorted.

Note that repeated non-adjacent lines in the input are only detected with the --global or -g option. In other words, unique output lines are guaranteed only if either (a) the --global or -g option is specified, or (b) the input lines are sorted.

Reads the file specified by its {@code path} and compares adjacent lines, writing one copy of each input line on the output. The second and succeeding copies of repeated adjacent input lines are not written to the output.
Note that repeated non-adjacent lines in the input are only detected with the --global or -g option. In other words, unique output lines are guaranteed only if either (a) the --global or -g option is specified, or (b) the input lines are sorted.

command-def.options:
[-c|-d|-u][-f fields][-s char]
Precedes each output line with a count of the number of times the line occurred in the input.
Suppresses the writing of lines that are not repeated in the input.
Suppresses the writing of lines that are repeated in the input.
Suppresses repeated lines globally, that is, if lines are non-adjacent. This option guarantees unique output lines even if the input lines are not sorted.

operands.operand: The files or directories used as starting point for the listing.
The files or directories used as starting point for the listing; wildcards * and ? are supported.
The options defining the uniqueness details for the output lines.
